Topic.Title: Radical Islamists And The Democrats

Message.Msg: LMAO right, load up your Bushmasters and shoot this heinous, terrorist-abetting immigration bill dead, or at least full of holes. Let's review....Obama is using the same FBI, CIA and armed military resources and tools (oops, my apologies to any tools offended by the label) as Bush did, but Obama has them pursuing ........ practically an identical agenda, and employing pretty much the same policies and strategies as the Shrub: tightened borders, elevated surveillance and screening of suspicious actors; 'directed' drone strikes against 'enemy combatants' on foreign soil; and foreign invasions and occupations (not wars; those cowards in Congressmen wouldn't dare besmirch their sterling reputations by declaring one). The difference? Obama has failed to demonize all Muslims or their faith, and instead tries to encourage the good ones while condemning the fringe extremist bad guys. Dang, why haven't we applied the far more logical neocon approach to Italians or Mormons, too? Both groups broadly embrace religions whose tenets and practice differ from those of Middle America, and both contain notorious but small criminal elements (the Italians have their Mafia and Catholic priests; Mormons have Warren Jeffs and his sect, plus Mitt Romney LOL). Buddy, you couldn't reason your way out of a pair of Chinese fingercuffs ROTFLMAO but I'll bet you could scream about the evil, diabolical Chinese who made your life a living hell......."Attack Beijing, and bar all immigrants from China...ROTFLMAO don't strain your back lugging that huge brain of yours to Wally World and back....

Message.Title: News for 'BAC' - (DJ MARKET TALK: BofA to Benefit from Cost Cutting -Morgan Stanley)
Message.Msg: 11:17 EDT - Morgan Stanley upgrades Bank of America (BAC) to overweight from equalweight as it believes the bank is digging itself out of the post financial crisis hole. Firm expects BAC to report earnings of $1.43 next year, 14 cents more than the average analyst estimate, and expects it to buy back 25% more of its stock in 2014 than in 2013. "Expense declines more than offset bear case litigation risk," firm said, and the "tail risk significantly lower with the settlement of [three] class actions in 1Q." BAC shares gain 3% to $12.07

BAC loans, as was well as tarp loans to the other megabanks, one of the better things the gov't has done for the tax payers. Tarp was a necessary and successful program. You have no idea how close the banking sysstem came to melting down in the fall of '08. That failure would have put at least 50 million out of work, if the great depression experience is any guide.

Message.Title: Obama's budget proposal aims revenue enhancement gun at smokers' heads
Message.Msg: And why not? Even the most far-right Congressman will agree to more taxes on cigarettes; the number of smokers is too small to threaten their incumbency, and they know it. That's why, at every tier of government - federal, state, county and local - the first things every grandstanding politician and two-bit legislative body in our fair land reach for when "times are tough and belts need to be tightened" are a cigarette pack and a tax stamp. Devoid of vision, talent and brains, our fatheaded, lardassed hacks, er, 'representatives', can be counted upon to pick up the same old tool - a hammer - and beat any shortfalls in THEIR bloated budgets out of the pockets and wallets and hides of what is already one of the slimmest segments of the population. Taxes on pate fois gras and filet mignon and fast food would spread the tax burden among a much broader (LOL) cross-section of the populace (and one that could really benefit from some bel-tightening); even raising gas taxes would be less regressive than cigarette or food taxes, and might encourage greater numbers of people to reduce their driving and tighten their belts by getting some exercise. Ah, the genius of leadership.....and these zealous defenders of liberty have shown time and time again that if one of their pet initiatives hasn't achieved its goal, the answer is always "more of the same until it works". ROTFLMAO how long will it take them to create a black market for homegrown tobacco, and then reconvene to address the desperate shortfalls in law enforcement resources, DAs, courts, and prisons? We're doomed, doomed: a dying nation of tampon praisers, ball-smugglers, and sheep.

Message.Title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Hong Kong
Message.Msg: To: andrea.b.smith, brian.t.moynihan, terry.laughlin, glynch, Cathy.bessant, tom.montag, david.darnell, Martin Hill, the head of technology infrastructure of BAML HK, literally said this to my face at my job interview: "I am not going to ask you any technical questions. I don't know anything about technology". Then at my first day at work, he literally said this to me: "Go through the company's fxcking compliance training. It's a waste of time, I would just click through them." I know very well I am not the ONLY person to whom Martin Hill made such statements. Martin Hill brought me in to work on the X project. Soon after I joined, he literally told me that "the U.S. has their own agenda. We in Asia are nimble and should be able to move forward much faster. etc. We don't have a developer here, and we need a developer. etc" Yet when things turned sour between him and the U.S. team, he fired me on March 26 (just five weeks and two days after I came on board), without any advanced warnings. Prior to that, neither Brad Lay nor Martin Hill and I had one single 1:1 meeting. Bank of America is paying Martin Hill as the head of technology infrastructure in Hong Kong who said he knew nothing about technology and told a new hire at his first day at work to "go through the company's fxcking compliance trainings by just clicking through them". Brad Lay, my direct reporting manager, who only has high school education, and acknowledges that he does not know anything about software development, is tasked by Martin Hill with managing and leading the X project and dictates people how to do development. And what company was this guy with before joining Bank of America? Electronics Arts, which was ranked as the worst company in America in 2012, followed by Bank of America being the second worst! With this kind of people on the helm, this bank is racing to the bottom fast IMO.
